natural problem: When $11^4$ is written out in base 10, the sum of its digits is $16=2^4$. What is the largest base $b$ such that the base-$b$ digits of $11^4$ do not add up to $2^4$?  (Note: here, $11^4$ in base $b$ means that the base-$b$ number $11$ is raised to the fourth power.)
natural solution: In any base, $11 = 10+1$, so we can think of $11^4$ as $(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)$. Expanded out, this is $$10^4 + 4(10^3) + 6(10^2) + 4(10) + 1.$$In base 7 or higher, this can be written as $14641$ (just as in base 10).
Put another way, when we multiply out $11\times 11\times 11\times 11$ in base 7 or higher, there is no carrying, so we get $14641$ just as in base 10.
However, in base 6, we have to carry from the $100$'s place, so we get $15041_6$, whose digits do not add up to $2^4$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: int and digit_sum :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "digit_sum (b^4) = 16"
and h1 : "\<forall>b. b < 6 \<longrightarrow> digit_sum (b^4) = 2^4"
shows  "b = 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $11^4$ is written out in base 10, the sum of its digits is $16=2^4$. What is the largest base $b$ such that the base-$b$ digits of $11^4$ do not add up to $2^4$?  (Note: here, $11^4$ in base $b$ means that the base-$b$ number $11$ is raised to the fourth power.) The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In any base, $11 = 10+1$, so we can think of $11^4$ as $(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)$. Expanded out, this is $$10^4 + 4(10^3) + 6(10^2) + 4(10) + 1.$$In base 7 or higher, this can be written as $14641$ (just as in base 10).
 Put another way, when we multiply out $11\times 11\times 11\times 11$ in base 7 or higher, there is no carrying, so we get $14641$ just as in base 10.
 However, in base 6, we have to carry from the $100$'s place, so we get $15041_6$, whose digits do not add up to $2^4$.
 So the answer is $b=\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: int and digit_sum :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "digit_sum (b^4) = 16"
and h1 : "\<forall>b. b < 6 \<longrightarrow> digit_sum (b^4) = 2^4"
shows  "b = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the integer $b$ such that the sum of the digits of $b^4$ is 16. Given that for all $b$ less than 6, the sum of the digits of $b^4$ is $2^4$. The final answer is $b=6$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat and base :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "base b = [1, 1]"
and h1 : "4 * b < 16"
shows  "b = 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $11^4$ is written out in base 10, the sum of its digits is $16=2^4$. What is the largest base $b$ such that the base-$b$ digits of $11^4$ do not add up to $2^4$?  (Note: here, $11^4$ in base $b$ means that the base-$b$ number $11$ is raised to the fourth power.) The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In any base, $11 = 10+1$, so we can think of $11^4$ as $(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)$. Expanded out, this is $$10^4 + 4(10^3) + 6(10^2) + 4(10) + 1.$$In base 7 or higher, this can be written as $14641$ (just as in base 10).
 Put another way, when we multiply out $11\times 11\times 11\times 11$ in base 7 or higher, there is no carrying, so we get $14641$ just as in base 10.
 However, in base 6, we have to carry from the $100$'s place, so we get $15041_6$, whose digits do not add up to $2^4$.
 So the answer is $b=\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat and base :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "base b = [1, 1]"
and h1 : "4 * b < 16"
shows  "b = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Assume that the base of a number $b$ is $[1, 1]$. Find the value of $b$ for which $4b < 16$. The final answer is $6$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat and sum_digits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> b. b \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> sum_digits (11 ^ 4) b \<noteq> 2 ^ 4"
shows  "b = 6"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $11^4$ is written out in base 10, the sum of its digits is $16=2^4$. What is the largest base $b$ such that the base-$b$ digits of $11^4$ do not add up to $2^4$?  (Note: here, $11^4$ in base $b$ means that the base-$b$ number $11$ is raised to the fourth power.) The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In any base, $11 = 10+1$, so we can think of $11^4$ as $(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)$. Expanded out, this is $$10^4 + 4(10^3) + 6(10^2) + 4(10) + 1.$$In base 7 or higher, this can be written as $14641$ (just as in base 10).
 Put another way, when we multiply out $11\times 11\times 11\times 11$ in base 7 or higher, there is no carrying, so we get $14641$ just as in base 10.
 However, in base 6, we have to carry from the $100$'s place, so we get $15041_6$, whose digits do not add up to $2^4$.
 So the answer is $b=\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat and sum_digits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> b. b \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> sum_digits (11 ^ 4) b \<noteq> 2 ^ 4"
shows  "b = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find a natural number $b$ greater than $1$ such that the sum of the digits in base $b$ representation of $11^4$ is not equal to $2^4$, for all $b$ up to $6$. The final answer is $6$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat
assumes h0 : "b \<le> 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> b. b \<le> 10 \<longrightarrow> sum_list (digits (b * b * b * b)) \<noteq> 2 powr 4"
shows  "b = 6"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $11^4$ is written out in base 10, the sum of its digits is $16=2^4$. What is the largest base $b$ such that the base-$b$ digits of $11^4$ do not add up to $2^4$?  (Note: here, $11^4$ in base $b$ means that the base-$b$ number $11$ is raised to the fourth power.) The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In any base, $11 = 10+1$, so we can think of $11^4$ as $(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)$. Expanded out, this is $$10^4 + 4(10^3) + 6(10^2) + 4(10) + 1.$$In base 7 or higher, this can be written as $14641$ (just as in base 10).
 Put another way, when we multiply out $11\times 11\times 11\times 11$ in base 7 or higher, there is no carrying, so we get $14641$ just as in base 10.
 However, in base 6, we have to carry from the $100$'s place, so we get $15041_6$, whose digits do not add up to $2^4$.
 So the answer is $b=\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat
assumes h0 : "b \<le> 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> b. b \<le> 10 \<longrightarrow> sum_list (digits (b * b * b * b)) \<noteq> 2 powr 4"
shows  "b = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find a natural number $b$ less than or equal to 10 such that the sum of the digits of $b^4$ is not equal to $2^4$. The final answer is 6.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat and sum_base_b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>b. sum_base_b (11^4) \<le> 2^4"
and h1 : "sum_base_b (11^4) = 16"
shows  "b \<le> 6"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $11^4$ is written out in base 10, the sum of its digits is $16=2^4$. What is the largest base $b$ such that the base-$b$ digits of $11^4$ do not add up to $2^4$?  (Note: here, $11^4$ in base $b$ means that the base-$b$ number $11$ is raised to the fourth power.) The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In any base, $11 = 10+1$, so we can think of $11^4$ as $(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)$. Expanded out, this is $$10^4 + 4(10^3) + 6(10^2) + 4(10) + 1.$$In base 7 or higher, this can be written as $14641$ (just as in base 10).
 Put another way, when we multiply out $11\times 11\times 11\times 11$ in base 7 or higher, there is no carrying, so we get $14641$ just as in base 10.
 However, in base 6, we have to carry from the $100$'s place, so we get $15041_6$, whose digits do not add up to $2^4$.
 So the answer is $b=\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat and sum_base_b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>b. sum_base_b (11^4) \<le> 2^4"
and h1 : "sum_base_b (11^4) = 16"
shows  "b \<le> 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: For a base $b$, define the function $sum\_base\_b$ as the sum of the digits when a number is expressed in base $b$. If the sum of the digits of $11^4$ in base $b$ is less than or equal to $2^4$ for every $b$, and if the sum of the digits of $11^4$ in base $b$ equals 16, then find the maximum possible value for $b$. The final answer is $b \leq 6$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "sum_list (digits b (11^4)) \<noteq> 2^4"
shows  "Max {b. b > 1 \<and> sum_list (digits b (11^4)) \<noteq> 2^4} = 6"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $11^4$ is written out in base 10, the sum of its digits is $16=2^4$. What is the largest base $b$ such that the base-$b$ digits of $11^4$ do not add up to $2^4$?  (Note: here, $11^4$ in base $b$ means that the base-$b$ number $11$ is raised to the fourth power.) The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In any base, $11 = 10+1$, so we can think of $11^4$ as $(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)$. Expanded out, this is $$10^4 + 4(10^3) + 6(10^2) + 4(10) + 1.$$In base 7 or higher, this can be written as $14641$ (just as in base 10).
 Put another way, when we multiply out $11\times 11\times 11\times 11$ in base 7 or higher, there is no carrying, so we get $14641$ just as in base 10.
 However, in base 6, we have to carry from the $100$'s place, so we get $15041_6$, whose digits do not add up to $2^4$.
 So the answer is $b=\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "sum_list (digits b (11^4)) \<noteq> 2^4"
shows  "Max {b. b > 1 \<and> sum_list (digits b (11^4)) \<noteq> 2^4} = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the greatest natural number $b$ larger than 1 such that the sum of the digits in the base $b$ representation of $11^4$ is not equal to $2^4$. The final answer is $6$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: int and p :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "b > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> b. p b = sum_digit (b powr 4)"
and h2 : "p b < 2 powr 4"
shows  "b \<le> 6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $11^4$ is written out in base 10, the sum of its digits is $16=2^4$. What is the largest base $b$ such that the base-$b$ digits of $11^4$ do not add up to $2^4$?  (Note: here, $11^4$ in base $b$ means that the base-$b$ number $11$ is raised to the fourth power.) The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In any base, $11 = 10+1$, so we can think of $11^4$ as $(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)$. Expanded out, this is $$10^4 + 4(10^3) + 6(10^2) + 4(10) + 1.$$In base 7 or higher, this can be written as $14641$ (just as in base 10).
 Put another way, when we multiply out $11\times 11\times 11\times 11$ in base 7 or higher, there is no carrying, so we get $14641$ just as in base 10.
 However, in base 6, we have to carry from the $100$'s place, so we get $15041_6$, whose digits do not add up to $2^4$.
 So the answer is $b=\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: int and p :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "b > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> b. p b = sum_digit (b powr 4)"
and h2 : "p b < 2 powr 4"
shows  "b \<le> 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a positive integer $b$, let $p(b)$ be the sum of the digits of $b^4$. If $p(b) < 2^4$, what is the maximum possible value of $b$? The final answer is $6$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat
assumes h0 : "b \<ge> 2"
and h1 : "11 powr 4 mod b \<noteq> 2 powr 4"
shows  "b \<le> 6"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $11^4$ is written out in base 10, the sum of its digits is $16=2^4$. What is the largest base $b$ such that the base-$b$ digits of $11^4$ do not add up to $2^4$?  (Note: here, $11^4$ in base $b$ means that the base-$b$ number $11$ is raised to the fourth power.) The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In any base, $11 = 10+1$, so we can think of $11^4$ as $(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)$. Expanded out, this is $$10^4 + 4(10^3) + 6(10^2) + 4(10) + 1.$$In base 7 or higher, this can be written as $14641$ (just as in base 10).
 Put another way, when we multiply out $11\times 11\times 11\times 11$ in base 7 or higher, there is no carrying, so we get $14641$ just as in base 10.
 However, in base 6, we have to carry from the $100$'s place, so we get $15041_6$, whose digits do not add up to $2^4$.
 So the answer is $b=\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat
assumes h0 : "b \<ge> 2"
and h1 : "11 powr 4 mod b \<noteq> 2 powr 4"
shows  "b \<le> 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: For a natural number $b$ that is greater than or equal to $2$, if $11^4$ mod $b$ is not equal to $2^4$, then $b$ is less than or equal to $6$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat and sum_digits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> b. b > 6 \<longrightarrow> sum_digits (11^4) b \<noteq> 2^4"
shows  "b = 6"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $11^4$ is written out in base 10, the sum of its digits is $16=2^4$. What is the largest base $b$ such that the base-$b$ digits of $11^4$ do not add up to $2^4$?  (Note: here, $11^4$ in base $b$ means that the base-$b$ number $11$ is raised to the fourth power.) The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In any base, $11 = 10+1$, so we can think of $11^4$ as $(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)$. Expanded out, this is $$10^4 + 4(10^3) + 6(10^2) + 4(10) + 1.$$In base 7 or higher, this can be written as $14641$ (just as in base 10).
 Put another way, when we multiply out $11\times 11\times 11\times 11$ in base 7 or higher, there is no carrying, so we get $14641$ just as in base 10.
 However, in base 6, we have to carry from the $100$'s place, so we get $15041_6$, whose digits do not add up to $2^4$.
 So the answer is $b=\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat and sum_digits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> b. b > 6 \<longrightarrow> sum_digits (11^4) b \<noteq> 2^4"
shows  "b = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: For what value of $b > 6$ does the sum of the digits of $11^4$ in base $b$ not equal $2^4$? The answer is $b=6$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat and sum_digits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> b. b > 6 \<longrightarrow> sum_digits (11^4) b \<noteq> 2^4"
shows  "GREATEST b. sum_digits (11^4) b \<noteq> 2^4 = 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When $11^4$ is written out in base 10, the sum of its digits is $16=2^4$. What is the largest base $b$ such that the base-$b$ digits of $11^4$ do not add up to $2^4$?  (Note: here, $11^4$ in base $b$ means that the base-$b$ number $11$ is raised to the fourth power.) The final Answer is 6

 In any base, $11 = 10+1$, so we can think of $11^4$ as $(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)(10+1)$. Expanded out, this is $$10^4 + 4(10^3) + 6(10^2) + 4(10) + 1.$$In base 7 or higher, this can be written as $14641$ (just as in base 10).
 Put another way, when we multiply out $11\times 11\times 11\times 11$ in base 7 or higher, there is no carrying, so we get $14641$ just as in base 10.
 However, in base 6, we have to carry from the $100$'s place, so we get $15041_6$, whose digits do not add up to $2^4$.
 So the answer is $b=\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat and sum_digits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> b. b > 6 \<longrightarrow> sum_digits (11^4) b \<noteq> 2^4"
shows  "GREATEST b. sum_digits (11^4) b \<noteq> 2^4 = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the greatest natural number $b$ such that the sum of the digits of $11^4$ in base $b$ is not equal to $2^4$. The final answer is $6$.
